newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - Feb 13.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - Feb 13.

text.p: The following stories were reported in Thursday's electronic version of The Wall Street Journal:
* The Dow industrials surged 103.52 points to a record 6,961.63, with a resurgance in technology stocks leading the way and pushing the Nasdaq up 27.45 to 1,358.96. The dollar continued to rise.
* American General is expected to announce a pact to pay up to $1.8 billion for USLife, plus the assumption of $600 million in debt.
* Pilots of AMR's American Airlines rejected a new contract proposal that raised the company's pay offer by one percentage point but cut stock options.

* ITT Corp rebuffed Hilton Hotels' hostile $6.5 billion bid and said it would sell its non-core assets. The company also filed a suit saying Hilton misused confidential information and failed to reveal all facts to shareholders.
* AT&T is offering an unadvertised special that would give customers an unlimited dime-a-minute long-distance rate.
* Investors put about $24 billion of new money into stock mutual funds in January, almost double December's inflow.
* Japan's trade surplus is likely to rise this year because of the weak yen.
* B.A.T Industries has indicated it might consider an industrywide pact to end U.S. tobacco litigation under certain conditions.
* Prescription drug prices rose 4.1 percent last year, above the 3.2 percent overall consumer inflation rate.
* A racial discrimination suit against S C Johnson & Son could make employers reconsider using worker teams without supervisors.
* Former U.S. Labor Secretery Lynn Martin made a number of recommendations for improving the workplace of Mitsubishi's U.S. auto plant, which was the subject of a federal sexual harassment suit.
* Bell Atlantic said one of its executives will take over the daily operations of the new company to be created after the merger with NYNEX.
* TWA named acting chief executive Gerald Gittner chairman and chief executive.

* With American Airlines pilots threatening to strike Saturday, the risks for investors in parent AMR Corp could hardly be more stark. While a quick settlement would boost the stock, a long walkout could trigger a steady fall. -- Heard on the Street.
* The jury is still out on whether inflation-indexed bonds will prove to be a home run with investors - or just a solid base hit. -- Credit Markets.
